repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
1. Update descriptions in help. Wordings are taken almost verbatim from [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/language-extensions/semantic-highlight-guide#standard-token-types-and-modifiers). With (slightly annoying) differences:
    1. That table contains `label` token type which is missing in [spec](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#textDocument_semanticTokens). Did not include it, assuming specification has higher priority.
    1. Specification contains `modifier` token type. Decided to include it in help file with a vague description.
1. Add support for some token modifiers:
    1. `@lsp.mod.defaultLibrary` links to `Special` so as to consistently highlight anything "built-in" as `Special`.
    2. `@lsp.mod.deprecated` links to `DiagnosticDeprecated` as the closest alternative.

comment_data.body:
To render this list with "flow" layout (as all Nvim-owned help pages must be), would you mind adding a `-` before each list item. See https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-api for an example of how a list is rendered.

Without this, the parser can't know if this is intended to be a list or a paragraph (soft-wrapped).

Alternative workaround is to put these in a codeblock.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -454,30 +454,44 @@ You probably want these inside a |ColorScheme| autocommand.
 Use |LspTokenUpdate| and |vim.lsp.semantic_tokens.highlight_token()| for more
 complex highlighting.
 
-The following groups are linked by default to standard |group-name|s:
-
-@lsp.type.class          Structure
-@lsp.type.decorator      Function
-@lsp.type.enum           Structure
-@lsp.type.enumMember     Constant
-@lsp.type.event          Type
-@lsp.type.function       Function
-@lsp.type.interface      Structure
-@lsp.type.keyword        Keyword
-@lsp.type.macro          Macro
-@lsp.type.method         Function
-@lsp.type.modifier       Type
-@lsp.type.namespace      Structure
-@lsp.type.number         Number
-@lsp.type.operator       Operator
-@lsp.type.parameter      Identifier
-@lsp.type.property       Identifier
-@lsp.type.regexp         SpecialChar
-@lsp.type.string         String
-@lsp.type.struct         Structure
-@lsp.type.type           Type
-@lsp.type.typeParameter  TypeDef
-@lsp.type.variable       Identifier
+The following is a list of standard captures used in queries for Nvim,
+highlighted according to the current colorscheme (use |:Inspect| on one to see
+the exact definition):
+
+@lsp.type.class          Identifiers that declare or reference a class type
+@lsp.type.comment        Tokens that represent a comment

comment_data.body:
Here are some more points:
- Technically, they now directly link to tree-sitter groups. Which won't be a valuable knowledge in on itself, in my opinion, as tree-sitter groups themselves are linked.
- This information feels like an implementation detail. And can be get by the user with `:Inspect` over the group name itself (as is described before the list).

 Use |LspTokenUpdate| and |vim.lsp.semantic_tokens.highlight_token()| for more
 complex highlighting.

comment_data.body:
> To render this list with "flow" layout (as all Nvim-owned help pages must be), would you mind adding a `-` before each list item. See https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-api for an example of how a list is rendered.
> 
> Without this, the parser can't know if this is intended to be a list or a paragraph (soft-wrapped).
> 
> Alternative workaround is to put these in a codeblock.

This follows the [similar documentation for tree-sitter groups](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/9765efb40f57b543d9fea610fb0d0f05b8387454/runtime/doc/treesitter.txt#L468-L585).

comment_data.body:
It's not working fine in "flow" layout. https://neovim.io/doc/user/treesitter.html#treesitter-parsers currently uses hardwrap layout.

Migrating to "flow" layout will eventually allow us to soft-wrap `:help` presentation in Nvim itself.

comment_data.body:
Is there a list somewhere I can see easily which files use this "flow" layout? Consider adding these (external) constraints to the `dev` documentation.

In any case, this is then a global issue and need not block this PR; I need to invest some time to find a solution that works for `:help` (which is the primary goal) and this flow layout. Both codeblocks (probably) and list markers (definitely) will break the former.

comment_data.body:
> Is there a list somewhere I can see easily which files use this "flow" layout?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/9765efb40f57b543d9fea610fb0d0f05b8387454/scripts/gen_help_html.lua#L58-L73

> Consider adding these (external) constraints to the dev documentation.

it's in `:help dev-doc`: 

     For Nvim-owned docs, use the following strict subset of "vimdoc" to ensure the
     help doc renders nicely in other formats (such as HTML:
     https://neovim.io/doc/user ).

> In any case, this is then a global issue and need not block this PR;

sure, doesn't need to block this PR.

comment_data.body:
List _items_ are soft-wrapped just like paragraphs/blocks.

Without list items (e.g. this PR), the block is treated as a one big paragraph/block, because the structure is not recognized. List items communicate the structure. 

There are numerous examples. Look at e.g. https://neovim.io/doc/user/api.html#api-metadata . A list item exceeding 80 chars is hard-wrapped in the vimdoc source, but correctly treated as one long line when parsed, which allows HTML to soft-wrap it.

comment_data.body: This is a table, though, _not_ a list... (So I don't want to wrap these, at all. And treating them as code blocks interferes with the highlighting, which is a big usability feature.)

comment_data.body: Yes, but tables currently aren't supported. Using a list doesn't (normally) cause any problem with `:help` rendering, so it's a reasonable workaround.

comment_data.body: So to handle this we need to support tables. In this case, using a list _does_ cause problems with this _specific_ help rendering (which is more complex due to the custom highlighting). I'll see if I can make it work somehow, but it's not clear to me how.

comment_data.body: If highlighting is somehow broken with a list, it may also be broken with table syntax (if that's ever implemented). Because tables would require some other syntax; it wouldn't be identical to what's currently here.

comment_regular_data.body: Yes, we only(!) care about the spec, not whatever VS Code hallucinates about it.

Is it alright that a `@lsp.mod.defaultLibrary` highlight will override many other highlights? For example the rust-analyzer LSP (understandably) gives this label to many tokens (built-in types, functions, etc.) and the `mod` group takes priority over the `type` group, meaning many highlights will get overridden, like default type, function, etc. highlights in the above example (unless the user/color scheme were to define a higher-priority `typemod` highlight)

> Is it alright that a `@lsp.mod.defaultLibrary` highlight will override many other highlights? For example the rust-analyzer LSP (understandably) gives this label to many tokens (built-in types, functions, etc.) and the `mod` group takes priority over the `type` group, meaning many highlights will get overridden, like default type, function, etc. highlights in the above example (unless the user/color scheme were to define a higher-priority `typemod` highlight)

Yes, having slept on this change I do agree that this is a bit too much to be placed in default color scheme (as it indeed severely affects user color schemes). I've reverted this.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: Increase support of LSP semantic tokens highlight groups
